unnormalised: Delhi residents are reeling from sticker shock after receiving their latest electricity bills. According to the Delhi Jal Board, water consumption has also seen a significant spike. Many households are reporting increases of 30% to 50% in their bills compared to the previous month. One resident, Mr. Sharma of Rohini Sector 7, shared that his electricity bill jumped from Rs. 3500 to Rs. 5200.

unnormalised: Officials from BSES Yamuna Power Limited (BYPL) and Tata Power Delhi Distribution Limited (TPDDL), the primary electricity providers, state that consumption patterns are seasonal. They note that electricity demand peaks during the summer months and dips during the winter. A TPDDL spokesperson advised consumers to conserve energy by switching to energy-efficient appliances like LED bulbs and ensuring proper insulation in their homes. Some residents, however, allege meter reading discrepancies, with some claiming their meter readings seemed unusually high, some upwards of 1000 units for the month.

unnormalised: The Delhi government has urged residents to use water and electricity judiciously and has also launched a public awareness campaign promoting energy conservation. They have also announced a helpline number, 1912, for residents to lodge complaints regarding billing issues. The government hopes that these measures will alleviate the burden on consumers and prevent excessive consumption in the future.
